2018-09-02.text: Sickle cell makes you different from other people, it makes you go through unbearable pain and forces you take certain precautions. Let’s all avoid this by breaking the sickle cycle.
I had a few attacks since then and every time I think it’s the last for me, I manage to pull through and here I am.
I felt helpless and it felt unreal even though I saw his corpse. I watched through the window as they washed him and I realized that that was it, he’s gone forever and now I’m in this all alone.

On the 3rd of November 2016, my brother passed away after a brief illness. I lost a part of me that day. All my life I’ve been having crisis and going through unbearable pain but that day I felt a different kind of pain.
Knowing all this, I made myself believe that if I was to die today then my brother had 7 more years to live.
My parents always told me that you only die when it’s your time and that I shouldn’t worry about all that.
In school we came to learn that sickle cell patients don’t make it past 21 years of age. It was really awkward as everyone turned to look at me in class that day.
He was the only one who truly understood what I was going through when in crisis.
We took our drugs together everyday, had appointments together and the same rules applied to both of us which made me feel like I had a partner in all of this.
As we got older I felt like I was responsible for him. My mom taught me to look after him and help him avoid the things he wasn’t allowed to do.

When I was 7, I finally had a little brother (my only brother) and a year later he too was sadly diagnosed with sickle cell anemia. It was really devastating because I didn’t want him to go through what I was going through.
As I got older it became normal for me and I stopped caring about the stuff I couldn’t do.
Growing up with sickle cell wasn’t easy at all. I couldn’t go for sleepovers, take cold water or do sports in school.

Hello! We would be sharing the beautiful and amazing  's Sickle Cell Story in a bit! 
#SeptemberSicklecellawarenessmonth

2018-06-18.text: Happy World Sickle Cell Day to the warriors we lost, we hope you are in a better place. To my SCD warriors hang in in there, I hope it gets easier, keep inspiring us not to give up with your unwavering courage. https://t.co/mfv8ryf5xk

2018-01-09.text: ✨Thank you for reading! Know your genotype let’s break the sickle cell cycle ✨

I am thankful to Allah and my parents for everything. I am a graduate and I am currently into fashion, beauty, and design creation.
Thank you! 
Anon.
Sicklers have the strongest hearts and minds. We wake up everyday with a new challenge.
Being a sickler is truly not easy. It requires a strong heart. Many people might hurt us knowingly or unknowingly because they don’t understand us.
I have faced a lot of stigma from people. I have been intimidated, disappointed, and lied to.

I suffered with osteomyelitis for 8 straight years. I was constantly out of school. It got to a point where I couldn’t walk, I started using crutches to walk. With the treatments and prayers I had, I got better. I started learning how to walk again.
As the years of physical, and emotional struggle passed, I developed osteomyelitis (bone infection) when I was 14.
I was admitted for months in the hospital. At 10, I had a severe case of abdominal crisis.

As a child, I was usually away from school because of unbearable crisis pains. 
At 3 years I had a painful swelling in my hand, this swelling is usually common in children with SCA.

Hello! I am 26 years old and I am a warrior of sickle cell anemia (SCA). For the 26 years l have lived, I have been through series of terrible problems due to SCA. My 26 years have been very emotional, depressing and traumatic.

Thread! An Anonymous warrior's Sickle Cell Story!✨

https://t.co/TEnJ124AV6

2017-12-01.text: 💫Thank you for reading Bilkisu Askira’s Sickle Cell Story! Know your genotype and let’s break the sickle cell cycle! Feel free to share your story!💫
I try my best to keep away from stress and I also keep myself healthy. I have learnt to take each day as it comes. Thank you for reading my story.
Living with sickle is a constant battle of uncertainty. The most astonishing thing about sickle cell is that no battle is the same and also no warrior is the same.
I also started having problems with my mental health and I was diagnosed with depression. I had therapy and I was also placed on antidepressants. I got better with the help of my amazing family.
My worst experience with sickle cell was in 2009 when I developed Acute Chest Syndrome, which is the leading cause of death in adults with SCA. I developed so many complications.
Then I remember that God only gives his hardest battles to his strongest warriors. I am always thankful. Sickle cell has its perks after all, but that is a whole different story.
On those days when I feel like I am being hacked with a chainsaw or when I feel like a butcher is attacking me with a knife, I keep asking my self “why me?”

Maybe I should just talk about the endless hospital stays, the numerous blood transfusions, the painkillers, the surgeries, the depression and the routine drugs I have to take everyday to help me function like a normal person. I could go on and on.

Whenever I am asked to talk about living with sickle cell anemia, I keep wondering where to start from. Do I start with the mild joint pains I wake up with everyday, or the excruciating ones that wake me up at 2 am? Or the gut wretching ones that make me scream out in pain?
Ever since I was diagnosed with sickle cell anemia, it has been a hell of a journey with a lot of highs and lows. I am thankful to Allah for seeing me through them all.
My name is Bilkisu Askira. I was born on the 24th of January and I am 27 years old. I am the first of 7 children and I was born with sickle cell anemia.
Thread! Read Bilkisu Askira's  Sickle Cell Story https://t.co/f8e0hOTHsV

2017-11-21.text: I stare at her as she wipes tears  off her face as the nurses poke my hand with needles, it breaks her heart seeing me like this and it also breaks my heart seeing her crying. She keeps me going! I love her!
I am so thankful for the amazing people I have in my life, especially my mother. When I can't sleep because of the pains, she is always awake with me.

I am perfectly normal and the next minute I am crying and I can't walk, I am carried around like a baby. It all happens so fast. You never know which day is going to be your last, so I accept each day as a gift.
My stubborn spirit is not for my fragile body. I heard that as you get older the frequency of your Sickle Cell crisis decreases, but the reverse is my case.
I have always been stubborn and I have always found it difficult to accept that I am different. I hate taking my drugs and the fact that my drugs are for life is so annoying.
I shouldn't be playing basketball at school or running around or dancing in the rain but I still do it anyway, fully aware of the consequences.
Constantly reminding me about how different I am. But it ain't all bad, Allah wants to see me like this.
Why are your eyes yellow? You are too small for your age. You will probably die before you are 18. Yeah people tell me that a lot.

Sickle Cell pushes you to your breaking point. It tries so hard to break you. It tends to drive you crazy. I wish for someone to talk to, someone who will truly listen and understand, but people don't really understand.
You know something about sickle cell? It doesn't just hurt like hell or maybe deform you, it messes with your mind, you get depressed no matter how strong and religious you think you are.
I reassure myself that Allah tests those he loves and it so happens that I have been tested a lot and so He loves me very much.
I try acting like it doesn't bother me or I don't care but deep down I know I care. I always laugh hard and smile to hide the pain. My inner self keeps asking the question "why me?"

Read  's article on living with SCA🎉🎉
https://t.co/sxGFN25ltw

2017-11-17.text: On the bright side, I am happy to be alive and I am thankful to Fatima for sharing my story with you. I am also thankful to God and my parents for all they have done. Thank you.
I am still a sickler and I still have crisis, and the pains are as bad as they have always been.
Words cannot explain how sad and disappointed we all were. I didn't go back for a third one cause my parents and I had had enough. We really spent so much money on it.
The "write off" as they eventually called me got better. My genotype was tested again and it had changed to AA. But it soon refracted back to SS.

To cut the story of their mistakes short, after they over did everything, they called me a write off. They called my dad to tell him that they had lost me. They later also called to tell him I was breathing again.
It made bubbles inside my lungs which were not expelling out. So they cut my chest open while I was conscious so that I could cough it out. The pain was terrible.
One of their many mistakes was that; a tube that was meant to pass through my neck to reach somewhere near my heart, was inserted into my lungs.
During my second transplant, the doctors made hella mistakes which almost cost me my life. Oh well, Nigeria for you!
The first bone marrow transplant I had was not successful because my body rejected the bone marrow. My parents still didn't give up, and we decided to try again.
I went through all the procedures required for me to get ready for the transplant and we were told about all the risks involved. I got a matching donor which was my sister.

When I was 14, we heard that the first bone marrow transplant in West Africa was carried out here in Nigeria, Benin to be precise. We were so happy, and my father decided we had to try it since it happened to be close and less expensive.
Ah but no, Sickle Cell was just getting started with me. Throughout my primary school, I have been more in the hospital than I have been in school.
After that crisis, I stared having crisis almost every week. I was young and everything was so confusing. I wanted it all to stop, I just wanted to be normal and live a normal life.
I seriously thought I would never be able to walk again, but eventually I did, after about a month in the hospital. That was when I experienced how truly terrible sickle cell is.
I remember my first terrible Sickle Cell crisis (Sickle Cell pain), I was 10 years old. The pain was unbearable, it felt like my knee was being hacked with a blunt knife.
Growing up with sickle cell is not easy and can never be easy. You keep wondering why you have to be different in such a painful way.
I was diagnosed with sickle cell anemia when I was a baby.I have 3 elder siblings whom all have the genotype AA.
I am Micheal Anyadoh and I am 18 years old. I am the last child of my parents and also the only child with SCA (Sickle Cell Anemia).

Read Micheal Anyadoh's Sickle Cell Story 🎉💃🏽 
https://t.co/pFXsNo6Hp0

does and don'ts. I try not to stress myself and I also keep myself happy with close friends.
I am taking care of myself and I work an 8-4 job with health insurance benefits. I take very good care of my self  and I strictly follow my
minute. The only sure thing is that you want to fight and stay alive. I am very grateful to Allah cause he had my back through all odds.
Living with sickle cell everyday is like being on a battlefield! Full of uncertainty, you can never tell what might happen in the next
I started shaking uncontrollably until I passed out. I woke up 4 days later.
was about to burst open. I was in so much pain, words cannot describe the intensity of my pain. I couldn't walk, stand, sit or do anything.
to and I developed Acute Chest Syndrome and then right after I had an Anemic Heart Failure. It was so scary and terrible. I thought my heart
would have to be last year after I had a surgery and got my Gallbladder removed. My doctors didn't take care of me how they were supposed
He also said he wouldn't be able to manage 2 wives justly, so we had to divorce.                      My worst experience with sickle cell
It happened that my husband wanted more kids and he said it would be bad to ask me for more due to what happened with my last pregnancy.
I finally gave birth to Aisha! She was born prematurely via C.S because I had IUGR (intra uterine growth restraint). Aisha weighed 1.65kg!
hospital for 2 weeks. My life then was basically 2 weeks in the hospital and 2 weeks at home. I was on lots of analgesics and IV fluids.
her daddy and everyone around us. I had to get blood transfusions every 2 weeks with 2 pints of blood and I also had to stay at the

them all.
I got married and I had a lovely daughter Aisha. A lovely gorgeous girl.
Being pregnant with her were very tough days for me,
For the 34 years I have lived, it has been 34 years of highs and lows, ups and downs, and a lot of gratitude to Allah for seeing me through
My younger sister who was also born with SCA died in 2001.
My name is Fatima Umar. I was born on the 4th of September. I am the second of 3 children and I was born with Sickle cell Anemia(SCA).
